''ampeloprasum''''' |trinomial = ''Allium ampeloprasum'' var. ''ampeloprasum'' }} '''Elephant garlic''' (''[[Allium ampeloprasum]]'' var. ''ampeloprasum'') is a plant belonging to the [[Allium|onion genus]]. It is not a true [[garlic]], but actually a variant of the species to which the garden [[leek (vegetable)|leek]] belongs. It has a tall, solid, flowering stalk and broad, flat [[Leaf|leaves]] much like those of the leek, but forms a bulb consisting of very large, garlic-like cloves. The flavor of these, while not exactly like garlic, is much more similar to garlic than to leeks. The flavor is milder than garlic, and much more palatable to some people than garlic when used raw as in salads. ==Cultivation== [[image:Ackerknoblauch (Allium ampeloprasum).JPG|thumb|left|Bulb size of elephant garlic]] The mature bulb is broken up into cloves which are quite large and with papery skins and these are used for both culinary purposes and propagation. There are also much smaller cloves with a hard shell that occur on the inside of the bulb. These are often ignored, but if they are planted, they will the first year produce a non-flowering plant which has a solid bulb, essentially a single large clove. In their second year, this single clove will break up into many separate cloves. Elephant garlic is not generally propagated by seeds. The plant, if left alone, will spread into a clump with many flowering heads. These are often left in flower gardens as an [[Ornamental plant|ornamental]] and to discourage pests. ==Properties== When crushed and then analyzed using a [[DART ion source]], elephant garlic has been shown to produce both [[allicin]], found in garlic, and [[syn-propanethial-S-oxide]] (onion lachrymatory factor), found in [[onion]] and [[leek]], but absent in garlic, consistent with the classification of elephant garlic as a closer relative of leek than of garlic.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Block E, Dane AJ, Thomas S, Cody RB|year=2010|month= |title=Applications of Direct Analysis in Real Time–Mass Spectrometry (DART-MS) in ''Allium'' Chemistry. 2-Propenesulfenic and 2-Propenesulfinic Acids, Diallyl Trisulfane ''S''-Oxide and Other Reactive Sulfur Compounds from Crushed Garlic and Other Alliums|journal= Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry|volume= 58 |pmid=20225897|issue= 8|pages= 4617–4625|id= |doi =10.1021/jf1000106}}</ref> == References == {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{commons category|Allium ampeloprasum}} *[http://www.nvsuk.org.uk/growing_show_vegetables_1/garlic_elephant_1.php Garlic and Elephant Garlic, National Vegetable Society (UK)]{{dead link|date=January 2013}} *[http://www.growyourown.info/page145.html Photos showing the different stages of growth of elephant garlic] {{Allium}} [[Category:Allium]] [[Category:Garlic]] [[Category:Perennial vegetables]] [[Category:Root vegetables]]
